questions.question: Which statement best defines a programming paradigm
options: A fixed algorithm for solving a class of problems
A general style of program design that shapes how problems are modeled and solved
A programming library for accessing hardware efficiently
A naming convention for variables and procedures
questions.answer: A general style of program design that shapes how problems are modeled and solved

questions.question: Which set best describes the paradigms explicitly?
options: Low-level, object-oriented, declarative, imperative including procedural
Low-level, object-oriented, declarative, graphical
Object-oriented, declarative, pipeline, lifecycle
Declarative, procedural, testing, validation
questions.answer: Low-level, object-oriented, declarative, imperative including procedural

questions.question: Match each paradigm to its primary characteristic.

pairs.Low-level programming: Works close to the processor with explicit control of memory
pairs.Imperative programming: Specifies a sequence of steps to achieve a result
pairs.Object-oriented programming: Bundles state with operations that act on that state
pairs.Declarative programming: Specifies what must be satisfied rather than how to compute it

questions.question: A __________ is a fast storage location inside the processor used during calculations.
questions.answer: register

questions.question: Which description characterizes low-level programming?
options: Hides hardware details behind high-level goals
Works close to the processor with explicit control of memory and registers
Focuses on rules and goals rather than computation steps
Organizes code into procedures with limited shared state
questions.answer: Works close to the processor with explicit control of memory and registers

questions.question: Match each addressing mode to its description.

pairs.Immediate: The data value is part of the instruction itself
pairs.Direct: Instruction contains a memory address where the data is stored
pairs.Indirect: Instruction points to a memory location that holds another address where the data is stored
pairs.Indexed: Effective address equals a base location plus the value in an index register
pairs.Relative: Finds a location by moving a small number of steps from the current instruction location

questions.question: Which statement correctly describes low-level conditional control flow?
options: A conditional label moves execution to a branch when a condition is met
A label evaluates a condition and jumps if true
A conditional branch moves execution to a named label when its condition is met
A branch stores data into a label register
questions.answer: A conditional branch moves execution to a named label when its condition is met

questions.question: According to good practice in low-level programming, you should
options: Write instructions first, then analyze memory usage afterward
Plan the sequence of memory accesses and register usage before writing instructions
Avoid using labels for conditional branches
Execute loops without checking stated conditions
questions.answer: Plan the sequence of memory accesses and register usage before writing instructions

questions.question: What distinguishes imperative programming?
options: Specifies what must be satisfied without steps
Specifies a sequence of steps that update program state in a controlled way
Restricts programs to facts and rules in a knowledge base
Prohibits side effects
questions.answer: Specifies a sequence of steps that update program state in a controlled way

questions.question: In imperative programming, __________ is all the information stored at a moment in time.
questions.answer: state

questions.question: A __________ is any change to program state that remains after a step finishes.
questions.answer: side effect

questions.question: In OOP, an __________ bundles state with the operations that act on that state.
questions.answer: object

questions.question: in OOP, a __________ is a blueprint that defines the attributes and methods shared by its objects.
questions.answer: class

questions.question: An object is an __________ of a class.
questions.answer: instance

questions.question: __________ keeps attributes hidden behind a public interface so changes occur only through defined operations.
questions.answer: Encapsulation

questions.question: Accessors and mutators primarily
options: Execute helper logic with no effect on state
Read and update hidden attributes while applying validation rules
Replace constructors and destructors
Convert declarative goals into imperative steps
questions.answer: Read and update hidden attributes while applying validation rules

questions.question: Which design guidance is explicitly given for interfaces?
options: Expose all internal attributes for flexibility
Keep interfaces minimal and purposeful, exposing only what client code must use
Avoid interfaces to reduce complexity
Put all validation in subclasses
questions.answer: Keep interfaces minimal and purposeful, exposing only what client code must use

questions.question: Match each relationship concept to its definition.

pairs.Inheritance: Subclass reuses and extends a superclass in an is-a relationship
pairs.Polymorphism: Different subclasses respond to the same operation name appropriately to their type
pairs.Overloading: Multiple operations share a name if their required inputs differ
pairs.Containment/Aggregation: One class owns or organizes other objects as part of its structure in a has-a relationship

questions.question: When should inheritance be preferred over containment?
options: When objects share any attribute
When the object truly is-a the base type and can be used in its place
When classes are unrelated but need to share state
Whenever reuse is desired regardless of type meaning
questions.answer: When the object truly is-a the base type and can be used in its place

questions.question: Candidate classes are identified by
options: Scanning the problem text for verbs
Scanning the problem text for nouns
questions.answer: Scanning the problem text for nouns

questions.question: What is the stated role of construction and destruction?
options: Construction allocates resources and sets valid initial state; destruction releases resources when objects are no longer needed
Construction validates other classes; destruction triggers inheritance
Construction handles user interfaces; destruction enforces polymorphism
questions.answer: Construction allocates resources and sets valid initial state; destruction releases resources when objects are no longer needed

questions.question: Which phrasing captures the essence of declarative programming?
options: Specify how to compute results step by step
Specify what must be satisfied rather than how to compute it
Specify only object lifecycles and interfaces
Specify only addressing modes
questions.answer: Specify what must be satisfied rather than how to compute it

questions.question: In declarative programming paradigm, a __________ contains facts and rules that model the problem domain.
questions.answer: knowledge base

questions.question: Match each declarative term to its description.

pairs.Fact: A simple, unconditional truth recorded about the domain
pairs.Rule: A way to infer new truths by combining existing facts
pairs.Goal: A question to be satisfied using available facts and rules

questions.question: Match each pipeline step to its description.

pairs.Record facts: Simple unconditional truths become building blocks
pairs.State rules: Define how new truths can be inferred by combining facts
pairs.Ask a goal: The system searches for matches and returns answers that satisfy the goal
